David,

That is certainly true, but you could say the same for many of the =
assert functions. For example, instead of assertNull one could use assertTr=
ue(x =3D=3D null) or assertEquals(x, null). The assertNull function looks n=
icer, of course, but it can be done. In the same vein, an assertEmpty, whil=
e not necessary functionally, would provide the benefit of cleaner looking =
code, in my opinion.

Best,
Mark


> On Oct 4, 2015, at 10:14 PM, David Saf=
f saff@... [junit] <junit@yahoogroups.com> wrote:
> 
> 
> Mark,
> 
>=
 Thanks for your mail.  Your idea sounds intriguing.  However, it seems tha=
t assertEquals(Optional.none(), x) or assertEquals(Optional.of(y), x) would=
 provide most of the benefit, wouldn't they?
> 
>    David
> 
> On Sun, Oct=
 4, 2015 at 1:55 PM, Mark Silvis masilvis22@... <mailto:masilvis22@gm=
ail.com> [junit] <junit@yahoogroups.com <mailto:junit@yahoogroups.com>> wro=
te:
>  
> I would like to contribute to JUnit, and I think I have a good id=
ea for a feature. I=E2=80=99ve found that it would be nice to have assertio=
ns that explicitly supported Java 8=E2=80=99s Optional class. I=E2=80=99m t=
hinking something along the lines of assertEmpty() and assertPresent(). Wou=
ld such an addition be welcomed?
> 
> Thanks,
> Mark
> 
> 
> 
> 


--Apple-Mail=_151FF0E6-A438-4560-AF68-265DE6FD2360
